p: The median range of over half of the species (52.7%) shifted at least 5 km northwards, while in the longitudinal gradient 38.5% of species moved eastwards and 31.4% westwards (Fig. 3). Patterns of both latitudinal and longitudinal shifts in median ranges between species having lost ranges, gained ranges, and species with no change in occupied squares differed significantly (latitudinal χ 2 = 56.85, p < .001, df = 8; longitudinal: χ 2 = 35.94, p < .001, df = 8). Median ranges of species with gained ranges moved the most, on average 23.88 km northwards and 8.88 km eastwards (20°), whereas those of species having lost ranges moved on average 13.56 km northwards and 3.25 km westwards (347°), and median ranges of species with no change in numbers of occupied squares moved 8.94 km northwards and 2.2 km westwards (346°).
